triples.name: Argumentation Theory
triples.relevance: Core interdisciplinary framework for studying computational models of argument and how conclusions are supported through logical reasoning.

triples.name: Formal Logic
triples.relevance: Mathematical approach to studying valid inferences and logical truths used in computational argumentation.

triples.name: Graph Theory
triples.relevance: Mathematical framework for modeling argumentation structures as graphs with nodes and edges.

triples.name: Cognitive Science
triples.relevance: Interdisciplinary study of mind and cognition that informs understanding of human argumentation processes.

triples.name: Bayesian Network
triples.relevance: Probabilistic graphical model used to represent uncertainty and relationships in computational argumentation systems.

triples.name: Fuzzy Logic
triples.relevance: Form of logic handling partial truth and vagueness useful for representing imprecise argumentation.

triples.name: Multi-Agent System
triples.relevance: Framework for modeling scenarios where multiple autonomous agents engage in argumentation and reasoning.

triples.name: Algorithm
triples.relevance: Finite sequence of computational instructions for solving argumentation-related problems and solvers.

triples.name: Text Mining
triples.relevance: Process of extracting information from text used for mining arguments in natural language texts.

triples.name: Argument Mining
triples.relevance: Automatic extraction and identification of argumentative structures from natural language text.

triples.name: Dialogue System
triples.relevance: Computer systems designed to engage in dialogue and argumentation with human users or other agents.

triples.name: Argumentation Framework
triples.relevance: Formal framework in artificial intelligence for dealing with contentious information and drawing conclusions.
